course.subject: CORE
course.name: Behavioral Foundations of University Education: Habits, Mindsets, and Wellness
course.description: This course will help students adapt to university life through advising, sharing and discussion, and applying the science of well‐being to enhance their personal and interpersonal development. It also aims to foster their self‐understanding and confidence as young adults who can fully enjoy their university education and career thereafter. The course has 3 components: Lectures and Seminars, Self‐Directed Experience, and Advising and Community Meetings. Lectures and Seminars will orientate students to their respective Schools/IPO, provide academic advices and equip them with the scientific bases of well‐being. Self‐Directed Experience will provide opportunities to develop mindsets and habits for students’ physical and social‐emotional wellness and personal enrichment. In Advising and Community Meetings, students will bring knowledge and skills together through reflection and discussion with peers and School/IPO advisors. Topics such as learning and time management skills, purpose of university education, and planning for personal and professional development will be covered. Graded PP, P or F.

reviews.author: syuuu
reviews.comment_content:
1. Online Lectures and Seminars: simple zoom sessions and solve fairly easy questions after watching videos

2. Self‐Directed Experience: join sports classes of your choice and attend 3 hours of activities provided, either online or offline. If you show up, it's done.

3. Community Meetings: Meet with your program advisor twice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pass or fail.
Nothing to worry about if you do all the required activities and go to the sports classes, which could be fun if you choose interesting ones.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload other than the self-directed experiences, which you need to attend.

reviews.author: It's time
reviews.comment_content:
Courses Intended Learning Outcomes
1 Explain well-being, physical and mental, and its importance
2 Demonstrate a capacity to take care of personal wellness using a variety of theories, practices, and experiences
3 Develop sustainable habits promoting personal and interpersonal development and well‐being while in University and beyond
4 Demonstrate self‐awareness and a capacity to self‐manage, set and pursue goals and respond to challenges and failure

The outcomes are just nonsense and not very helpful so I would just leave a C here.
reviews.comment_teaching: No teaching so no comments on this aspect
reviews.comment_grading: The course in only graded in Pass or Fail. As long as you attend the compulsory face-to-face meeting and zoom meeting, you would be fine to get a pass.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 Real Time Online lecture
Dozens of survey + 4 Online modules
at least 15 hours, including at least 9 hours in Sports Skill Class and at least 3 hours in Wellness & Personal Enrichment OR Community Engagement/Services

It seems there are a lot of things to do but the surveys are just MC and are short in length (except the intake survey and the Mood and Stress Assessment (DASS) Survey). They wouldn't require you too much time to finish them though most of them are required to be done before November.

reviews.author: Wendy_pvq
reviews.comment_content:
The course has 3 components: Lectures and Seminars, Self‐Directed Experience, and Advising and Community Meetings.

Lectures are done via online video, you just base on the video and the power point and answer the question with mostly correct is okay.

Self-directed experiences are separated into two parts, one is attending 3 hours of online or offline activities provided by the HKUST Engage. Another is joining the sports classes provided by the school which are held in Fall or Spring depending on your class. For me, I studied that in the Spring sem.

Last but not least is the Community Meetings that are held twice in the whole semester, both of them are held in the form of talk. Mainly focus on mental health and future job issues.
reviews.comment_teaching: The video is a pre-recorded video, there are no limitations on the time of watching. For the sports classes, I took the badminton class, and they mainly taught the basic skill. Therefore, it is not really difficult, but have to remember that you could only be absent 2 times for the class, otherwise, you might not be able to fulfill the requirement.
reviews.comment_grading: This course is only graded in PP (pass) or Fail. You must get a pass as long as you fulfill the course requirement.
reviews.comment_workload: Easy workload. Most of the questions are common sense questions or able to find answers on the internet. Besides the video and some questionnaires, there is no more homework to do.

reviews.author: ian.lau
reviews.comment_content:
3 Zoom sessions about major selection, exchange, etc.
5 pre-recorded videos about psychological stuff with quizzes
1 AAAC group meeting and let AAAC know you know what you are doing and you understand what you need to do to graduate
2 Community meetings with program advisor
2 Reflection exercises
Do at least 9 hours of sports skill classes, and an additional 6 hours of either sports skill class or self directed workshops (15 hours in total)
1 Intake Survey
1 Psychological Wellness Survey
1 First Year Experience Survey
reviews.comment_teaching: Fair, mostly just informational stuff from powerpoints
reviews.comment_grading: You get a pass as long as you finish all required assessments~
reviews.comment_workload: Just a general mandatory informational course, no study required, make sure you finish all required assessments

reviews.author: cutelilcat
reviews.title: Average course that isn’t really helpful
reviews.comment_content:
The course comprises the following parts:
1) Lectures: There were 3 compulsory zoom lectures on 3 Mondays in September, and 5 videos we needed to watch on Canvas and complete relevant quizzes afterwards
2) Advising and community meetings: Meet with your AAAC once in the fall semester, and attend 2 community meetings in the spring semester
3) Reflection journals: To be completed in the spring semester
4) Self-directed workshops: Need to take part in 9 hours of sports skills class (1905C is given priority to reg sport skills class in spring), and 6 hours of self-directed experience, eg attending core1905-recognised zoom meetings. An advice would be to attend the workshops in summer first to lower your workload after sem starts.
5) Surveys: have some surveys to fill in with deadlines
reviews.comment_teaching: Not much teaching is involved, the zoom lectures are rather informative (eg about major selection). The Canvas self-paced videos were a little too slow, but they were short and so were not burdensome to watch.
reviews.comment_grading: Pass or fail, so won’t affect your GPA; but you must make sure you complete every compulsory item (even though there are make-up lectures from my understanding).
reviews.comment_workload: Quite low, since there are no exams, no studying is required. Just need to make sure to reserve time to complete the small tasks (eg the quiz after each self-paced video, intake survey…) and attend the lectures/ sports skills classes.

reviews.author: jesuisfatiguée
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures (20%)
1. Attend 3 compulsory real-time online (RTO) lectures in Fall 2022-23
2. Watch 5 online self-paced lecture videos and complete quizzes with at least 80% of all questions answered correctly in Fall and Spring 2022-23

Advising and Community Meetings (10%+10%)
- 1 small group meeting with AAAC in Fall 2022 with the Educational Plan completed
- 2 community meetings in Spring 2023

Reflection Journals (20%)
- 2 reflection journals related to the 2 community meetings in Spring 2023

Self-Directed Experience Workshops (20%)
- Complete at least 15 hours, including at least 9 hours in Sports Skill Class

Surveys
- Complete the following compulsory questionnaires/surveys:
(a)  Intake Survey
(b)  Psychological Wellness Survey DASS
(c)  First Year Experience Survey (FYES)
reviews.comment_teaching: The zoom meetings gave us an overview on UST life. It was informative, but as it's held over zoom, it's definitely not engaging.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload, you just have to log in to zoom for the RTO lectures. For the assignments, you have to watch the self paced videos first in order to unlock the quiz. You may have to search for extra information online as not all the answers are covered in the videos.
